Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
assetchains file mods?
```
function komodo_asset ()
{
    if [ $[RANDOM % 10] == 1 ]
    then
        gen=" -gen"
    else
        gen=""
    fi

    if [ -n "$2" ]
    then
        supply=" -ac_supply=$2"
    else
        supply=" "
    fi

    if [ -n "$3" ]
    then
        ac_reward=" -ac_reward=$3"
    else
        ac_reward=" "
    fi

    $komodo_binary -ac_name=$1 $gen $supply $ac_reward $args -pubkey=$pubkey -addnode=$seed_ip &
    sleep $delay
}

#set -x
komodo_asset RFOX 1000000000 100000000
```

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
```
#!/bin/bash
curl -s -o ~/contrib/stats/summary.json https://komodostats.com/api/notary/summary.json
for ASSET in `cat ~/komodo/src/assetchains | grep komodo_asset |grep -v "function" | grep -v "PIZZA\|BEER" | awk '{print $2}'`
do
TMP_STATS_BLOCK=$(cat ~/contrib/stats/summary.json | jq --arg a "${ASSET}" '.[] | select(.ac_name==$a)|.blocks')
STATS_BLOCK=$((${TMP_STATS_BLOCK} + 0))
MY_BLOCK=$(komodo-cli -ac_name=${ASSET} getinfo | jq '.blocks')
if [ ${STATS_BLOCK} -ne ${MY_BLOCK} ]
then
  echo "BLOCK DIFFERENCE FOR ${ASSET}: ${STATS_BLOCK} AND MY ${MY_BLOCK}"
  if [ ${STATS_BLOCK} -ne $(expr ${MY_BLOCK} - 1) ]
  then
    echo ">>>>>>>ERROR: ${ASSET} ${STATS_BLOCK} AND ${MY_BLOCK}"
  fi
else
  echo "OK: ${ASSET}: Stats ${STATS_BLOCK} vs MY ${MY_BLOCK}"
fi
done
```

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
Would anyone be in favour of having some kind of standardised JSON file in the Komodo repo of all asset chains with args NNs should be running. Something like:

```js
[
  {
    "ac_name": "ZILLA",
    "ac_supply": "11000000",
    "addnode": "54.39.23.248"
  },
  {
    "ac_name": "RFOX",
    "ac_supply": "1000000000",
    "ac_reward": "100000000",
    "addnode": "78.47.196.146"
  }
  ...
]
```

The idea being that the main repo doesn't provide an init script, but just the required meta data. All NNs are free to build their own init scripts that loop over the provided array without having to hardcode asset chain params and try and keep them in sync with the komodo repo.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: I am all for this... as are a heap of other people. @patchkez  has been pretty outspoken about this in the past.  I am using my own scripts for the most part, and its getting hard to manage them now. Soe kind of standard is def the way to go.

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: It would make it so much easier going forward

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: everyone can have their own scripts, and James just needs to update a single  file and know all NNs will use that

This config should be then used by all other scripts (m_notary_run, assetchains). Config file should have also addnotary IPs, The thing is that some of these data already exists in coins/ folder in Supernet repo.

Author: patchkez#5349
Content: then next to this central config file, operators could have another json config e.g. with just his changes e.g. pubkey, walletpassphrase, or he could overide values which are defined in central config file

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: JSON is parsable with `jq`, but it's quite complex

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
```
$ cat assetchains.json
[
  {
    "ac_name": "ZILLA",
    "ac_supply": "11000000",
    "addnode": "54.39.23.248"
  },
  {
    "ac_name": "RFOX",
    "ac_supply": "1000000000",
    "ac_reward": "100000000",
    "addnode": "78.47.196.146"
  }
]

$ cat assetchains.json | jq '.[] | to_entries | map("-\(.key)=\(.value|tostring)") | reduce .[1:][] as $i ("\(.[0])"; . + " \($i)")'
"-ac_name=ZILLA -ac_supply=11000000 -addnode=54.39.23.248"
"-ac_name=RFOX -ac_supply=1000000000 -ac_reward=100000000 -addnode=78.47.196.146"
```

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I like the idea of having JSON as it's more powerful but maybe it's not the best format for this

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: it might be better to just list the args

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
e.g something like:
```
$ cat assetchainparams.txt
-ac_name=ZILLA -ac_supply=11000000 -addnode=54.39.23.248
-ac_name=RFOX -ac_supply=1000000000 -ac_reward=100000000 -addnode=78.47.196.146
```

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: super easy to loop over in bash

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: and for more powerful usage you can manually parse the params
